title: Before 1 July 2018, will Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte proclaim martial law nationwide?
preds: Just a few days left so I'm going with no.

http://bulatlat.com/main/2018/05/26/disturbing-proposal-martial-law-imposition/ ".  . . .the consultative committee (con-com) which Duterte formed to recommend charter changes towards shifting to a federal system of government has unanimously approved an amendment to the provision cited above: adding “lawless violence” to invasion and rebellion as another reason for the imposition of martial law. Retired Lt. Gen. Ferdinand Bocobo, a con-com member, said he suggested the amendment in view of present challenges to national security posed by “terrorism and violent extremism” to which, he added, acts of lawless violence are related. Replying to a question, he claimed that “simultaneous or large-scale” attacks by the New People’s Army would be enough reason for the President to impose martial law. “For NPA attacks to fall under ‘terrorism’ as ground to declare martial law, these attacks should cause widespread and extraordinary fear and panic among the populace,” he explained. (He was referring to the provision of the Human Security Act of 2007, the anti-terrorism law.) But retired SC associate justice Eduardo Nachura, a con-com subcommittee head, goes even farther. “Lawless violence,” he said, ‘does not have to be widespread as a ground to declare martial law or suspend the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus.” As if it hadn’t been easy enough for him to have his way in Mindanao, now the President’s men seem to be thinking up more ways to make it even more of a breeze, next time around!
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I agree that the proposed changes will make it easier for Duterte to declare martial law, however, I do not think he will do so until the changes are enacted.

Today's headline is:
Philippine Chief Justice, a Harsh Critic of Duterte, Is Ousted 
No doubt, this will make it easier for Duterte to get away with proclaiming martial law, but I think that he'll let things cool off a bit  and that this question will close  before he does.
Articles were posted a year ago. The conflict in Mindanao is localized.
Dropping lower because I haven't heard anything pushing Duterte toward declaring nationwide martial law.
I have been following this question for months and as nothing has made it look any more likely so I am assuming Duterte has dropped the idea.
Standing pat. There's no martial law throughout most of Mindanao, let alone the hundreds of other islands that constitute the Philippines .

The only other incident since 1900 of martial law was under Marcos from 1972-1981 when fighting the communists and he was a dictator. So 9 out of the last 118 years, which is 7.6% of the time (with three months to go put it at 1.9%). Duterte stated in May of last year that nationwide martial law is possible if he felt the north had a terrorist stronghold, which I don't see any evidence of or near-term escalation, but the odds are higher now then an average non-local martial law situation. I would put my estimate at around 3%, and average between the wisdom of the crowd currently at 5%, so I will say 4%.
Any additional declarations of martial law would likely continue to be confined to specific regions (not nationwide).

He really doesn't seem to need to in order to get away with doing what the hell he wants so why would he? It also ties up a lot of resources rather than keeping them available for deployment in the light of any trouble.

Rebels are in exile, extreme measures taken already to avoid more rebellion, focus on natural disasters and humanitarian aid, elections, high economy aspirations,...The government is very unlikely to let rebels make any gains and will do everything to keep them in check and provide some stability for the country, making martial law an unlikely solution - which doesn't mean there is no repression, but I don't see how martial law, and the chaos it brings, would serve any of Duterte's agendas right now. https://reliefweb.int/report/philippines/philippines-humanitarian-bulletin-issue-3-april-2018

The reason he declared martial law on Mindinao was because ISIS was trying to get a foothold in the country and martial law was the best way to crush it. If ISIS becomes a serious threat he will but he just can't do it arbitrary because of Filipino law and bitter memories from Marcos when he declared martial law in the 80s

Two reasons: 1) 1 July is four months away, a very short time period. 2) General Lorenzana, who oversees the implementation of Martial Law in Mindanao where government forces are battling ISIL-affiliated elements, clarified that "that is very remote [option] to happen right now".
 (https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/day-rage-president-duterte-170926114614352.html)

2017
Jan. 31: Amnesty International releases a report claiming that "this is not a war on drugs, but a war on the poor." It details allegations of police being paid up to $300 per kill, as well as evidence-planting and falsification of incident reports to cover up unlawful executions.
June 29: A Reuters investigation reveals that police are sending corpses to hospitals in an attempt to disguise the fact that they are executing suspects. The percentage of drug suspects pronounced dead-on-arrival in two districts increases from 13% to 85%.
Oct. 27: Duterte defends the campaign, claiming that allegations of extrajudicial killings are political attempts to "demonize" him.
2018
February: The International Criminal Court launches a preliminary inquiry into the drug war over claims of crimes against humanity, while the U.S. labels the Filipino leader a threat to democracy. Duterte's administration hits back, asserting that he is not a threat to democracy, but rather a threat to the criminals who seek to destroy it.
https://www.axios.com/timeline-rodrigo-dutertes-war-on-drugs-1519224206-d18fd3d0-3af1-4a9e-910c-a4e367e6dfed.html How a secretive police squad racked up kills in Duterte's drug war

https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/philippines-duterta-doa/ Police tell one story of what happened in Barangay 19. Security cameras tell another.

COMMENTS:  Perhaps July 1, is too early for a Nationwide proclamation--even a dictator has to be discreet--but it won't be too far away. And i do wonder how many drug dealers are left alive by now.
Flipping to opposite. My biasometer was duterte and too pessimistic during the late September media coverage.
He already has an iron fist on the country.  No need to go to that extreme.

With time his strategy has come across as totalitarian and authoritarian throughout the world's democratic powers.. his surge, has leveled and more than anything he is on damage control, plus economically, and logistically manning such move is simply not in the interest of progress
Duterte appears to have enough popularity which makes this an unneeded option.

Duterte seems to be making overtures to the Military, elevating their status and salaries so that they will provide support should he decide to enact universal martial law. Without military support, this action would be meaningless. The military leaders are also in tune with international voices though, so they could decide that it is not in the Philippines interest to  go along with it if outside pressure is strong enough. I think Duterte is too careful of a leader to risk establishing martial law if the military is not entirely support, and I don't think he will be able to do this at all, let alone in 4 months.
Interesting analysis, don't know how true this is though - https://www.rappler.com/nation/195737-duterte-revolutionary-government-martial-law-trillanes
He's too popular to need to.
Trump has made this more likely, but still a big step.
Probably not.  He's already declared it a free-fire zone.

He doesn’t need to declare martial law. He’s already getting all Terminator on his motorcycle. With talk of ICC, does he really want to double down on martial law. Still notionally a democracy and there will be elections.

Revising estimate significantly downward due to timeline and the fact martial law isn't even completely implemented across Mindanao let alone elsewhere nationally and the passage of time. I'm not seeing anywhere that the insurgency is getting worse or that terrorism is getting worse. I can't find anything more recent than october that provided any indication of Duterte's popularity or governing agenda suffering. I would look for things like that to emerge before considering an increase in likelihood.
Dropping a few points because Duterte hasn't been threatening this lately.

At this point it seems that all of Duterte’s declarations of martial law, and a lot of his most aggressive mandates have been against the southern island of Mindanao where he has repeatedly declared or extended martial law. I don’t think that he will receive the same support to extend it to the rest of the islands as he did against the south.

Duterte reaches for unlimited, unending power

"Muslims to Get Self-Rule to Avoid Another Bloody Separatist War in the Philippines"- This report indicates a fast track move by President Duterte and the Philippine Congress to pass the bill authorizing the Muslim part of the nation to have self-rule in the region. However, the current Martial Law is effective until the end of 2018. The bill means that Mindanao (Southern Philippines) mostly populated by Filipino-Muslim residents and home to Abu Sayaff, Moro International Liberation Front (MILF) as well as some various ISIS sympathizers could mean that self-proclaimed power by Islamic loyalist as well as MILF political umbrella could potentially run the entire Southern part of the country. In contrast, this could also mean a peaceful process and develop a small provincial government run by the local Islamic and MILF personnel. The potential that a full blown martial law for the entire country is less likely since Manila, and Visaya (Central part of the country) are predominantly Roman Catholic and remains a powerful player in Philippine government as well as local governments around the country.

Philippines' Duterte urges Congress to pass bill for self-rule in Muslim region
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-rebels/philippines-duterte-urges-congress-to-pass-bill-for-self-rule-in-muslim-region-idUSKBN1F71ER If the law is passed the Muslims are likely to lay down arms, having won autonomy.
Won't be Nationwide. Most likely Mindanao only

due to the length of time that has transpired since he threaten Martial law  and the small  decreases in conflict against Islamist extremists it would also seem like a more to plant himself as a possible dictator which would no doubt  remove his already strained international relations with the United States Australians  and others.

Due to his upscaling of non crimes, to answer with violence.  People will tip.

Duterte doesn't need martial law powers to act like a dictator or pursue a wide-ranging campaign of extra-judicial killing. The threat from militants is not nationwide. Until faced with a legitimate opponent in a national election this seems unlikely.

As the nationwide martial law has not taken place yet but has been extended in Mindanao it would seem that it is less likely to happen than I had previously thought.

No need for him to do this.  He has carte blanche to kill folks on Mindanao by the extension of martial law there, and permission from the US president to kill anybody who is suspected of anything in the rest of the country.

I find it hard to imagine its Congress approving a nationwide extension of martial law. Doing so would be equivalent to making Duterte a dictator. He seems to think he can declare a revolutionary government and that that would be preferable to martial law.

Trump and Duterte are reported to have discussed Duterte's war on drugs, and are likely to have discussed terrorism. Duterte says his war on terrorism is linked to his marshall law on Mindanao. My guess is that Trump will have admired Duterte's tactics and indicated that the US will not question Duterte's actions. This might encourage Duterte to extend the area of marshall law. (Much as he might be tempted Trump will probably not emulate Duterte in the US.)

Metro Manila (CNN Philippines, October 19) — President Rodrigo Duterte said Thursday martial law in Mindanao will continue until "the last terrorist is taken out." "When the time came, I declared martial law and everybody was asking, when will it stop? It will not stop until the last terrorist is taken out," Duterte said in a speech at the 43rd Philippine Business Conference and Expo concluding ceremony Thursday.
http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/10/20/Duterte-says-martial-law-to-remain-until-last-terrorist-is-taken.html Duterte administration
Main article: Proclamation No. 216 Proclamation Number 216 declaring martial law in Mindanao.
Amid the escalation of conflicts in Mindanao and recent clashes in Marawi City related to the Maute Group, incumbent President Rodrigo Duterte placed Mindanao and its nearby islands under martial law. This was announced during a briefing held in Moscow, where President Duterte was on an official visit, and will be in effect for 60 days. Presidential Spokesperson Ernesto Abella said the declaration was possible given the "existence of rebellion," while Foreign Secretary Alan Peter Cayetano explained that the step was taken with of "the safety, the lives and property of people of Mindanao" in mind. Implementation is to be pursuant to the 1987 Constitution, which provides for a maximum 60 day-state of martial law without Congress approval for extension, the continuation of government functions, and the safeguard of individual freedoms. However, President Duterte insisted that it will not be any different from martial law under President Marcos.
While the declaration does not currently affect citizens and government units in Luzon or the Visayas, President Duterte suggested that he might extend martial law to the entire country if needed to "protect the people."
__________________________
COMMENT:  I wonder what Duterte means by "last terrorist" or a definition of "terrorist", it is/will be just anyone that opposes his views probably. Martial Law is not news for the Philippines: Proclamation № 1081 was the proclamation of Martial Law in the Philippines by President Ferdinand E. Marcos. It was announced to the public on 23 September 1972, and was formally lifted on 17 January 1981.

The President of the United States of America has expressed great admiration for his programme of unbridled extrajudicial murder by the police and military, which is also popular with the home folks.  He does not need martial law, which might draw unwanted attention to the goings-on.

No need at the moment.  He is currently pretending to be a decent human being, with the full understanding that he can unleash death whenever he needs a bump in the polls, with or without the cover of martial law.  No wonder President LIttlefingers likes him so much.

Out of 195 countries, only 20 have ever proclaimed martial law over the course of history (20/195=0.1026): +10% Out of these 20 countries, the Philippines was one of them to declare martial law (1/20=0.05): +5.0% May 23, 2017, Duterte declared  martial law in Mindanao after IS attacks on Marawi City, and this was an extremely large scale attack. So it seems that Duterte is more likely to respond to large scale terrorist attacks with martial law compared to smaller scale ones. Now, looking at terrorism trends worldwide.... In 2016, there were a total of 11,072 terrorist attacks worldwide. Of those attacks, 55% of attacks occurred in Iraq, Afghanistan, India, Pakistan, and the Philippines (11,072/365=30.33). This is equivalent to having 30 terrorist attacks worldwide per day in one year. In 2015, there were 12,121 terrorist attacks worldwide. So the number of attacks has shown a decline since 2015. Of these 11,072 terrorist attacks in 2016, 482 were in the Philippines (482/11072= 0.0435). But in 2015, of 12,121 terrorist attacks, 490 of them were in the Philippines (490/12,121=0.0404), which shows that the rate of terrorist attacks in the Philippines has not declined dramatically compared to the worldwide results. So that means, on average, ((482+490)/2=486) there are about 486 terrorist attacks in the Philippines each year (in the past two years), which is about 1.3 terrorist attacks a day. So far, Duterte has been in office for a little over a year. Assuming the trend of terrorist attacks continues (here I am using the 2016 value for this estimate because the 2017 data is not available/I cannot find it), that means that only 1 out of the 482 attacks has incited Duterte to declare martial law (1/482=0.002). So the probability of having a terrorist attack in the Philippines and having an attack elicit martial law is 4%*0.2%=0.8%: +1% https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/272485.pdf So far, I predict a 10+5+1=16% chance of Duterte proclaiming martial law nationwide.  Legislators have voted to extend martial law in Mindanao to continue addressing the Islamist insurgencies. Although, Duterte has claimed that the city is now liberated (Oct 17). Government forces have allegedly killed the insurgents leader. Yet, this 5 month fight shows that that a relatively small militant group can keep government forces pinned down, which could inspire other militant groups into action in the future.  https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/17/world/asia/philippines-marawi-fighting.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FPhilippines&action=click&contentCollection=world&region=stream&module=stream_unit&version=latest&contentPlacement=1&pgtype=collection Yet, most Muslims live in Mindanao, so it is likely that most of the terrorist attacks will be isolated to that region of the Philippines, in which Duterte might keep martial law isolated to that region.
He will make sure his current kinder-gentler gesture is a failure, thus requiring him to declare martial law countrywide.
Duterte is calming down, it seems. Dateline 10-11-2017 https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/12/philippines-rodrigo-duterte-police-war-drugs
Following @Raahul_Kumar on the basis of data provided at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/587209

Duterte is said to be planning to lift it in Marawi; if he does, I may be flipping my forecast.

With total power why make this move? Martial law would not be good for good business and would risk dragging this country out of the international community. More likeky is a crack down against opponents
Seems that extending martial law would not be popular, maybe Duterte will listen, maybe not. Maybe he will wait for a good excuse (or create a good excuse)

He may decide that he and his minions can imprison and murder enough people without this step.  Hard to say just yet.

http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/2111330/philippine-president-duterte-may-declare-nationwide-martial
15 September, 2017, "Duterte may declare nationwide martial law if threatened protests by communists and other leftists against his rule turn violent or disrupt the country, his defence chief said  . . . Lorenzana emphasised he believed it was very unlikely martial law would be declared, but said the president was worried about threatened “massive” protests by the left.
“He said, if the left will try to have a massive protest, start fires on the streets, they will disrupt the country, then I might (declare martial law),” Lorenzana told reporters, recounting a conversation with Duterte this week.
“In my opinion, in my estimate the possibility of this happening is very remote. But the president is indeed very concerned because it might get out of hand.
So he said: ‘I might declare martial law’.”

Unless counter terrorism operations are needed in a larger area, martial law won't be declared. Duterte is achieving levels of violence in anti drug operations without the geopolitical costs of declaring wider areas of martial law. With his heavy hand, it's unlikely any unity of revolt materializes.
Trend is upward for Duterte, but low chance of any particular thing happening, generally
Duterte has actually mentioned martial law for the whole country now. http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/local-news/2017/09/10/duterte-warns-martial-law-nationwide-if-reds-stage-street-hostility
Unlikely the conflict is really limited to the south. He is quietly getting US military help in intelligence and aircraft strike capability. This conflict will not last thru the years end.

Current consensus is 30%. Should I go above or below?  Meta analysis: on average, any Gjopen question of the form, "Will event X occur before date Y?" resolves as "NO."  Given that I don't have a clue on what Duterte is going to do, therefore I'm edging below consensus merely on the basis of this metanalysis.
This one has a lot of uncertainty so I'm keeping it near the middle but tucking back toward the crowd.

Duerte is still very popular in the Philippines. Just because martial law has become a reality in Mindanao and nearby islands doesn't mean he will declare martial law everywhere in the Philippines before Jul 1 of next year. Violence has to increase a lot more for martial law to be declared nationwide.
I think it's too early to dismiss this.

As @Anneinak says, Duterte has said numerous times that martial law would allow him to deal more easily with the Filipine problems and as Duerte's hero President Marcos did. There seems to comparatively little popular opposition to Duterte's methods. I would suggest that having floated the idea of ML and finding the people seem to like having a strong leader who will do whatever it takes to get results, Duterte is just waiting for an event - terrorism, natural disaster, protest marches or whatever , to provide a good excuse for proclaiming ML.  If nothing comes up, then maybe something could be staged (as it has been suggested his hero Marcos did; I would suggest an IS attack would be ideal to ensure Chines, Russian and US support for ML). 
He presumably has calculated that the regional powers will not object. China sees the advantages of allowing leader to act rather than get involved in the type of  bureaucratic restraint that democratic processes involve. I am pretty sure Trump would admire and envy Durerte even more if he declared ML. Duerte would be aware that the US did not stop Marcos. 
I don't think that people like Duterte  care very much about the damage their actions cause such as the loss of the tourist trade. Populists crave power as long as they have power they are not really interested in the economy.

Comments to chiefjusticepanganiban@hotmail.com " . . . .President Duterte has . . . . said more than once (the latest being during his State of the Nation Address on July 24) that he was “not stupid” to impose ML nationwide because he knew only too well its constitutional constraints. I think that if he wanted to impose authoritarian rule, he would simply set aside the Constitution and rely on the brute power of the military and the police. "Truly, the 1987 Constitution has exorcised the evils of ML.  . . .  ML — under the present Charter — merely: "Facilitates the apprehension of suspects in the crimes of rebellion and invasion (but not in other crimes) and, with the concurrent suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus, allows the detention of the suspects for 72 hours (instead of the usual 36 hours). "Triggers some constitutional provisions that could give the President additional powers or restrict some constitutional rights, provided Congress passes implementing laws specifically defining those powers and rights. Notably, the President has not asked for, and Congress has not passed, such laws. "Bloated recognition. Consequently, I wonder why the military needed, and still needs, martial law. Other than facilitating the arrest and detention of rebellion suspects a little longer, ML has had, from where I sit, a limited role in suppressing the rebellion in Marawi and Mindanao. "On the other hand, the imposition of ML has unintentionally given bloated international recognition to the ability of the Mautes and the Islamic-State-connected group of Isnilon Hapilon to engage and, for a while, stymie our far more numerous, superiorly armed, and better trained military for more than three months now. This recognition gave the rebels the opportunity to acquire more logistics, funds and arms from other radical groups, to recruit more cadres and to prolong their terroristic agenda. "ML’s minuses. Foreigners still believe the traditional concept that ML automatically suspends the rule of law, suppresses civil liberties and imposes authoritarian rule. They are not aware of the strict limitations under our 1987 Constitution. Hence, they avoid places where ML reigns. "True, foreign tourist arrivals for the entire country grew 12.73 percent in the first half of this year to 3.36 million from 2.98 million in the comparable period last year. But arrivals in Mindanao have suffered cancellations precisely due to the perceived strength of the rebels that necessitated the imposition and extension of ML. "Likewise, some long-term investments in infrastructures and manufacturing have been put on hold. Closer to the poor, agriculture-based jobs have dissipated while private capital has become shy. "I am sure the Duterte administration is fully aware of these minuses. Nonetheless, it has asked for and received from Congress an extension of ML till Dec. 31. It must have some reasons beyond my reach as an ordinary citizen. "Given, however, that the final assault to wipe out the few remaining rebels is well on its way, the military could or can recommend ML’s termination soon. No law prevents the President from accepting such recommendation and ending ML at any time prior to Dec. 31. "By lifting ML (and the suspension of the privilege) early, the President will signal normalization in Mindanao. He will also be lauding the ability of the military to contain the uprising, moving forward, without any need to detain rebellion suspects for more than the usual 36 hours. "Moreover, he will also encourage the return of tourists and of long-term investments in Mindanao to create new jobs and to rev up the economy.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I'm reading that Duterte is starting to get pushback for all the "drug user/dealer" executions.  If there was to be mass protests,  I think Duterte wouldn't hesitate to impose martial law, justifying it as necessary to protect law, order, peace and security.

Big street demonstrations the other day against the officially sanctioned butchery, but only because they killed a kid.  However, if people keep being unhappy Duterte gets to claim widespread unrest and chaos and general havoc, giving him an excuse to declare martial law.  He really wants to do this, so it won' t take much.
Changing my mind on the basis of data and analyses by @Anneinak.

http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/08/20/1730812/independent-probe-urged-drug-slays "The government’s brutal war against illegal drugs is a deliberate move to create anarchy and give Malacañang a reason to place the entire country under martial law, according to a former military official. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the administration is bent on establishing a federal system of government, which he said could only be fast-tracked under military rule. “Any massive violent reaction from all these government security and peace and order actions – police brutal anti-drug operations, termination of the peace talks with the communists and the reported presence of terrorists in the country – are enough grounds to justify the declaration of martial law.” "The source said that even Kusug Tausug party-list Rep. Shernee Abubakar Tan of Sulu bared this plan when she declared that she was not only supporting the extension of martial law in Mindanao, but for President Duterte to impose it throughout the country. Tan had said that with the country under the military rule, it would be easy for the President establish a federal system of government.  “That declaration coming from a lady lawmaker from Mindanao was a clear sign that something, unknown to most, is in the drawing board of the present administration,” the source added. "When he assumed the presidency, Duterte declared that he wanted a federal system of government and that if he could do this in two to three years, he would be happy to leave Malacañang. The retired military officer also cited the siege in Marawi City, which prompted the President to declare martial law Mindanao. "Being an expert in threat assessment, the source said the New People’s Army (NPA) could also be used by the administration to push its plan change the form of government to a federal system.  “With the termination of the peace talks, any increase in NPA attacks across the country will justify the declaration of martial law which,” he said. "On the campaign against illegal drugs, he said any massive and violent public response would result in a military rule, as what happened in Mindanao after the Marawi siege. 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This article convinced me that martial law is the quickest way for Duterte to achieve his goal of establishing a federal system of government, and that just about any effort to oppose this  will be used as an excuse for declaring it.

The death of a 17-year-old has critics of President Rodrigo Duterte cautiously optimistic that public support for his drug war is eroding.  If so, it might  slow Duterte down from imposing martial law nationwide. Duterte said over & over that he'd not impose martial law and I believed him, then he did: once burned, twice shy.

- The event of a nationwide martial law is very unlikely to being with and the insurgency movement in Philippines is small and not nationwide
- But Duterte has been known to impose tough measures, so I'll give it a higher chance of happening.
A more predictable politician warrants a lower probability.

No new news on Duterte and martial law. That alone suggests extending it nationwide is unlikely. Wikipedia: As of 13 August 2017, the casualties reported are as follows:
562 militants killed (11 foreigners)
9 militants captured
128 government forces killed (12 by friendly fire)
60 government forces missing
900 government forces wounded
119 civilians dead (74 due to illness)
The police chief of Malabang, Romeo Enriquez, who was cited by Duterte as beheaded in his speech on 24 May 2017 as one of the basis for his declaration of martial law the day before, was found later to be still alive.The police officer killed was later identified by the ARMM PNP as Senior Inspector Freddie Solar, a former police chief of Malabang and member of the Drug Enforcement Unit of the Lanao del Sur Provincial Police. Along with the casualties, much of Marawi was flattened in what was described as the heaviest urban fighting in the Philippines since World War II.

Was it an overreaction for Duterte to impose martial law beyond Marawi to the whole island? His comments focused on the need to make sure the terrorism doesn't spread and that it's temporary. Then it was extended to the end of the year and some of his supporters indicated they would support keeping it in place until the end of his term in 2022.
He initially downplayed the existence of terrorism in the country as he fought his war on drugs aimed at his own people.
Would imposing martial law on the rest of the country show that he's losing the war on terrorism and it's spreading? Or is martial law just what he wants anyway? I'm not sure.  His comments from June...

http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/06/21/1712249/duterte-nationwide-martial-law-not-needed-time “Martial law is here. Whether or not I expand it to cover the entire the Philippines is something else. And at this time, it is not called for,” the president said in a press conference in Cagayan de Oro last Tuesday. Last November, Duterte said he would consider suspending the writ of habeas corpus if lawlessness spreads in Mindanao. He made the same remarks in May, saying he might suspend the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in the Visayas if fighting spills over from Mindanao. He also said he would declare martial law across the country if Islamic State-inspired militants gain a foothold in Luzon.

"Defense Secretary Delfin Lorenzana assured on Saturday that Luzon and Visayas would not be placed under martial law."

The Filipino Congress voted to extend martial law until the end of the year in the Southern islands.  ISIS is a formidable violent actor in the region and President Duterte, with US assistance, has responded with force.  President Duterte's detractors believe martial law is unnecessary to combat ISIS in the region and he is using the current situation to consolidate power.  If the US weren't so invested in the island state, I would forecast nationwide martial law as highly probably. A nearly $100 million dollar military aid package, among other US aid packages, would be at risk with nationwide martial law.  There are strings attached to US aid packages, and I believe the creation of a dictatorship would cut the strings.
